notes.note: Whereas Nordic m ilitary academies have arguably taught ‘War/Military Studies’ in relation to officers for considerably longer, academization of the military profession in the late 1990s arguably motivated a transformation of previously vocational knowledge into an academic format that lends for comparison with other university disciplines.

Note that there is a burgeoning literature on professional military education (PME). This literature (e.g. Higbee 2010; Johnson-Freese 2013, Gyllensporre 2014; Libel 2016 ; Larsson 2024 ; Enstad and Hagen 2025 ), however, focuses on reforms and pedagogy of military education. W e focus on War /Military Studies, which occasionally, but not always is understood to be one part of such military education.
See case-section 1, 2-3 specifically, in Olsen and Kristiansen (2007).
Kesseli (2007) and < https://maanpuolustuskorkeakoulu.fi/en/research > , accesse d 202 5-06-12 , as well as its counterpart in Finnish.
The dataset can be found on < http://www.university-autonomy.eu > (accessed 202 5-06-12 ) and is updated every six years .
See course description for “War in the Modern World”, < https://www.ntnu.edu/studies/courses/KRIG3020/2024#tab=omEmnet > , accessed 20 25-06-12 .

The master’s p rogram for the officer profession is however structured as a multidisciplinary degree in Military Studies, but this program is nonetheless organized as four separate majors where students select one , along the disciplinary divides described in the section.
